summary: This document is an email chain between defense attorney Laura Menninger and a federal prosecutor regarding discovery issues in the US v. Maxwell case. It focuses on discrepancies in the number of 'Highly Confidential' (HC) images and videos recovered from Jeffrey Epstein's devices, logistical problems with defense review of evidence, and the government's handling of sensitive materials. The chain reveals confusion over the count of HC materials (initially reported as ~5,500, but an FBI 302 indicates ~34,000) and details arrangements for the defense to review evidence in Colorado.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Lead defense counsel corresponding with prosecutors about discovery deficiencies, specifically regarding the review and count of 'Highly Confidential' images and videos seized from Epstein.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.role: Contractor (US Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York)
persons.context: Copied on email correspondence regarding discovery conferral in US v. Maxwell case.

persons.name: Chris Everdell
persons.context: Mentioned as having reviewed HC images with Ghislaine Maxwell at the MDC in fall 2020.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in US v. Maxwell; her defense team is seeking to review discovery materials, including HC images, with her.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: HC images and videos were recovered from his electronic devices and CDs seized from his New York and Virgin Islands residences.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Copied on some emails in the chain regarding discovery deficiencies.

connections.description: Menninger is defense counsel representing Maxwell in the criminal case, advocating for her access to review discovery materials.
Implicit in the case context; materials (HC images/videos) seized from Epstein are evidence in the prosecution of Maxwell.
Professional correspondence between defense and prosecution teams regarding discovery logistics and issues.
Everdell reviewed HC materials with Maxwell at the MDC in 2020.

events.title: HC Image Review at MDC
events.description: FBI agents brought a drive containing HC images from CDs for Chris Everdell to review with Ghislaine Maxwell at the Metropolitan Detention Center.

events.title: Second HC Image Review at MDC
events.description: FBI agents brought a drive containing HC images from CDs for a second review session with Ghislaine Maxwell at the MDC.

events.title: Defense Evidence Review in New York
events.description: Laura Menninger reviewed evidence, including two hard drives said to contain HC images, at 500 Pearl Street in New York.

events.title: Production of De-designated Materials
events.description: Approximately 7,721 images previously designated as HC were de-designated and produced as confidential materials.

events.title: Discovery Conferral on HC Materials
events.description: Email correspondence finalizing that the FBI confirmed the correct number of HC images (~26,947) were on drives for review in Colorado, addressing prior discrepancies.

Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC), likely in New York

keyFacts: A significant discrepancy existed between the number of 'Highly Confidential' (HC) images/videos initially conveyed to defense (~5,500) and the count in an FBI 302 report (~33,747 images + 895 videos). The prosecution later confirmed the 302 number was accurate.

The HC materials came from two sources: images recovered from CDs seized at Epstein's NY residence, and images/videos recovered from electronic devices seized during Epstein's arrest and searches of his NY and Virgin Islands residences.

The defense faced major logistical hurdles in reviewing discovery, including corrupt files, missing metadata, lack of proper software to view files, and restrictions on accessing HC materials only on government laptops under FBI supervision.
The prosecution was de-designating some HC images (those not depicting genitals, breasts, or buttocks) to Confidential status for production to the defense.

The email chain shows tense pre-trial negotiations over evidence access, with the defense expressing concern about reviewing tens of thousands of HC images close to the then-scheduled November 2021 trial date.
